bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, March 18, 1949

div1.p: Hench begs Moran to allow him to read his manuscript “My Date with Walter Reed and Yellow Jack” while Moran is still alive so that he can discuss it with him. He promises to keep it in confidence. Hench discusses the ongoing Camp Lazear memorialization campaign.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, March 18, 1949
div1.p:
Since dictating the enclosed letter, I have been to New York and back
and I have talked to the head of our Editorial Department. We are most anxious
to help you in any way possible. Doctor Hewitt of our Editorial Department is
also greatly worried because there is only one copy of your manuscript. He thinks
that you should have a copy made out and deposit it with trusted friends who will
only use it as you wish. Such things as fires, and tornadoes do occur. People
get sick and relatives come in and throw things away, etc., etc.

I should like to make you a proposition. If you are willing to send
your manuscript here, registered mail, we have a copying machine here that makes
not photostats, but what we call dry amoniated prints quite inexpensively and
effectively. We could make you two or three copies at no expense to you; if you
would continue to honor me by your confidence, I would keep one here to use only
as and when you wish and I could return the original and other copies to you,
one of which could be kept in your home, the others could be kept in your safe
deposit box. On the basis of the one you would allow me to keep, you and I could
have further friendly correspondence and if correspondence would bother you, I
could compare it with the notes I already have and perhaps make a questionnaire
which we could discuss easily and leisurely on my next visit to Cuba.

If you do not wish to send it here, may I urgently and earnestly make
a second proposition. Will you ask a stenographer to make two or three copies
of your manuscript at my expense or have your manuscript photostated at my expense,
sending me the negative photostats. We could have the positive photostats
made here.

All of the above is just an indication of how valuable your friends
know your manuscript is.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
